Fiction: THE BROKER, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $27.95.) The C.I.A. arranges a presidential
pardon for a power broker who may know crucial secrets, laying a trap for the foreign
intelligence service that wants him dead.
THE DA VINCI CODE, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The murder of a curator at the
Louvre leads to a trail of clues found in the work of Leonardo and to the discovery of a
centuries-old secret society.
SURVIVOR IN DEATH, by J. D. Robb. (Putnam, $23.95.) In 2059, Lt. Eve Dallas has an
eyewitness to the brutal murder of a family: the sole survivor, a 9-year-old girl; by Nora
Roberts, writing pseudonymously.
THE FIVE PEOPLE YOU MEET IN HEAVEN, by Mitch Albom. (Hyperion, $19.95.) An old
man who died while trying to rescue a little girl from danger discovers that all will be
explained to him in the afterlife.
STATE OF FEAR, by Michael Crichton. (HarperCollins, $27.95.) Reverse eco-terrorists
create natural disasters to convince the public that global warming is real.
CONVICTION, by Richard North Patterson. (Random House, $25.95.) A lawyer comes to
believe that her client — who is on death row for the sexual assault and murder of a young
girl — may be innocent.
BY ORDER OF THE PRESIDENT, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $26.95.) An Army officer
tries to thwart a terrorist plot to crash a stolen 727 into the Liberty Bell.
CHAINFIRE, by Terry Goodkind. (Tor/Tom Doherty, $29.95.) The 10th volume of the
"Sword of Truth" fantasy series.
LABYRINTH OF EVIL, by James Luceno. (Lucas/Del Rey/Ballantine, $25.95.) A new "Star
Wars" novel, featuring Anakin Skywalker and Obi-Wan Kenobi.
I AM CHARLOTTE SIMMONS, by Tom Wolfe. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.95.) A very
smart, very innocent freshman from the Blue Ridge Mountains is amazed by what she finds
at a prestigious university.
PREP, by Curtis Sittenfeld. (Random House, $21.95.) A scholarship student from South
Bend, Ind., encounters a world of privilege when she attends an expensive boarding school
in Massachusetts.
A SALTY PIECE OF LAND, by Jimmy Buffett. (Little, Brown, $27.95.) A cowboy's life is
changed forever when he meets a 101-year-old woman who hires him to be a lighthouse
keeper in the southern Bahamas.
NIGHT FALL, by Nelson DeMille. (Warner, $26.95.) A husband and wife who work for an
antiterrorism task force reopen the investigation into the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 over
the Atlantic, off Long Island, in 1996.
ALONE, by Lisa Gardner. (Bantam, $24.) A sniper with the Massachusetts State Police
February 20, 2005
Non-Fiction
BLINK, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) The author of "The Tipping
Point" explores the importance of hunch and instinct to the workings of the mind.
COLLAPSE, by Jared Diamond. (Viking, $29.95.) A historical investigation, by the
author of "Guns, Germs, and Steel," into why some societies succeed while others
fail.
AMERICA (THE BOOK), by Jon Stewart, Ben Karlin and David Javerbaum.
(Warner, $24.95.) "The Daily Show" offers a lavishly illustrated parody of a civics
textbook.
WITNESS, by Amber Frey. (ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $25.95.) A memoir by the
California massage therapist who testified for the prosecution in the murder trial of
Scott Peterson.
GOD'S POLITICS, by Jim Wallis. (HarperSanFrancisco, $24.95.) An evangelical
Christian argues that Democrats must "take back the faith" and not allow
conservative Republicans to hijack the Bible.
SECRETS & MYSTERIES OF THE WORLD, by Sylvia Browne. (Hay House,
$19.95.) The self-proclaimed psychic tries to explain the inexplicable.
ANIMALS IN TRANSLATION, by Temple Grandin and Catherine Johnson.
(Scribner, $25.) How autism can help lead to an understanding of the brains,
emotions and talents of animals.
DEAR SENATOR, by Essie Mae Washington-Williams and William Stadiem.
(ReganBooks/HarperCollins, $24.95.) A memoir by the mixed-race daughter of
Strom Thurmond.
102 MINUTES, by Jim Dwyer and Kevin Flynn. (Times Books/Holt, $26.) Two
journalists at The New York Times describe people's struggle to survive inside the
World Trade Center on Sept. 11.
WINNING THE FUTURE, by Newt Gingrich. (Regnery, $27.95.) The former
speaker of the House proposes a 21st-century "Contract With America."
CHRONICLES: VOLUME ONE, by Bob Dylan. (Simon & Schuster, $24.)
Recollections and observations from the singer/songwriter.
EATS, SHOOTS & LEAVES, by Lynne Truss. (Gotham, $17.50.) An
Englishwoman expounds on the use and misuse of punctuation marks.
HIS EXCELLENCY, by Joseph J. Ellis. (Knopf, $26.95.) A biography of George
Washington, by the author of "Founding Brothers."
FAVRE, by Brett Favre and Bonita Favre with Chris Havel. (N.F.L. Publishing/
RuggedLand, $29.95.) A profusely illustrated book about the Green Bay Packers'
